questions.question: For a car on a flat curve, if the radius of the turn is cut in half but the speed remains the same, the friction required to keep the car on the road:
questions.explanation: $f_s = mv^2/r$, so $f_s \propto 1/r$. Halving radius doubles required friction.

questions.question: A 0.1 kg ball on a string is whirled in a horizontal circle. If the string can only withstand 10 N of tension before breaking, what is the maximum speed it can have at a radius of 1 m?
A 2000 kg truck and a 1000 kg car take the same flat turn at the same speed. How does the required $\mu_s$ for the truck compare to the car?
options: It depends on the width of the tires.
questions.explanation: $\mu_s = v^2/(rg)$ is independent of mass, so they need the same $\mu_s$.

questions.question: Centrifugal force is:
options: A real force acting outward in circular motion
A fictitious force appearing in rotating reference frames
The same as centripetal force but opposite direction
The net force required for circular motion
questions.explanation: Centrifugal force is a fictitious force that appears only in rotating (non-inertial) reference frames.

questions.question: A 1200 kg car rounds a flat curve of radius 50 meters at a speed of 20 meters per second. What minimum coefficient of static friction is required between the tires and road to prevent skidding? (Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$)
On a banked curve with no friction, which component of the normal force ($F_N$) provides the centripetal acceleration?
options: The normal force does not provide centripetal acceleration.
questions.explanation: The horizontal component $F_N \sin\theta$ points toward the center and provides centripetal force.

questions.question: If a car exceeds the 'ideal speed' on a banked curve, in which direction must static friction act to keep the car from sliding?
options: Up the incline (away from the center)
Tangent to the direction of motion
questions.explanation: Above ideal speed, car tends to slide up incline, so friction acts down incline (toward center).

questions.question: For a coin on a rotating turntable, what happens if the angular speed ($\omega$) is increased beyond the limit $\sqrt{\mu_s g / r}$?
options: The coin moves toward the center.
The coin remains stationary due to inertia.
The coin slips and moves outward.
The friction coefficient increases to compensate.
questions.explanation: Beyond this limit, friction is insufficient to provide needed centripetal force, so coin slips outward.

questions.question: In horizontal circular motion, what is the value of the vertical acceleration?
options: It depends on the bank angle.
questions.explanation: In horizontal circular motion, there is no vertical acceleration; vertical forces balance.

questions.question: When engineers design a highway curve for 'ideal banking,' they are primarily accounting for:
options: Reducing wear and tear on the road.
Safety during icy or wet conditions.
Increasing the fuel efficiency of the cars.
questions.explanation: Ideal banking allows cars to negotiate curves without relying on friction, which is crucial for safety in icy/wet conditions.
